questions.text: Luteinizing hormone (LH) and human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) have similar biologic activity for which of the following reasons?

options.label: C
options.text: They are produced by the same pituitary cell type

options.label: D
options.text: They are converted to the same amino acid sequence peripheral

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Their β-subunits have 80% homology

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • LH, FSH, TSH and hCG are heterodimers consisting of a common glycoprotein α-subunit linked to a unique β-subunit, which provides functional specificity. The amino acid sequence of the human LH and CG β-subunits demonstrates approximately 80-percent similarity. This similarity between LH and hCG can have clinical sequelae.
  • • LH, FSH, TSH and hCG are heterodimers consisting of a common glycoprotein α-subunit linked to a unique β-subunit, which provides functional specificity.
  • • The amino acid sequence of the human LH and CG β-subunits demonstrates approximately 80-percent similarity.
  • • This similarity between LH and hCG can have clinical sequelae.
  • • Thus, answer is option A
  • • Thus, answer is option A
  • • Also, molar pregnancies frequently produce very high levels of hCG, which can bind to TSH receptors, resulting in hyperthyroidism.
  • • Also, molar pregnancies frequently produce very high levels of hCG, which can bind to TSH receptors, resulting in hyperthyroidism.
  • • Now, Let's go through each option separately:
  • • Now, Let's go through each option separately:
  • • Option A. Their β-subunits have 80% homology : This is the correct answer. Both LH and hCG are glycoprotein hormones consisting of alpha and beta subunits. While the alpha subunits are nearly identical between these hormones, it's the beta subunits that confer their unique biological activities. The β-subunits of LH and hCG share about 80% homology, meaning they are structurally similar but not identical. This significant degree of similarity in their β-subunits is what leads to their similar biological activities.
  • • Option A.
  • • Their β-subunits have 80% homology
  • • Option B. They have nearly homologous α-subunits : This statement is true but not the reason for their similar biological activity. The α-subunits of LH and hCG, as well as other glycoprotein hormones like follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), are indeed nearly identical.
  • • Option B. They have nearly homologous α-subunits
  • • They have nearly homologous α-subunits
  • • Option C. They are produced by the same pituitary cell type : This is not correct. LH is produced by gonadotropic cells in the anterior pituitary gland, while hCG is produced primarily by the placenta during pregnancy
  • • Option C.
  • • They are produced by the same pituitary cell type
  • • Option D. They are converted to the same amino acid sequence peripherally : This is also not correct. LH and hCG are secreted in their active forms and do not undergo conversion to a common amino acid sequence in the periphery. They exert their effects through interactions with specific receptors on target cells.
  • • Option D.
  • • They are converted to the same amino acid sequence peripherally

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Gynecology page 335, 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Gynecology page 335, 3 rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following is LEAST likely true of basal body temperature testing in the adult female?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be an insensitive test in many women

options.label: B
options.text: With ovulation, the temperature rises roughly 0.8°F

options.label: C
options.text: It is an inexpensive and easy test for ovulation monitoring

options.label: D
options.text: Once the temperature rises, a patient should expect ovulation in the next 12 hours

questions.correct_answer: D. Once the temperature rises, a patient should expect ovulation in the next 12 hours
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Once the temperature rises, a patient should expect ovulation in the next 12 hours

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Basal body temperature (BBT) charting has long been used to identify ovulation. This test requires that a woman’s morning oral temperature be graphically charted Oral temperatures are usually 97.0° to 98.0°F during the follicular phase. A postovulatory rise in progesterone levels increases basal temperature by approximately 0.4° to 0.8°F. This biphasic temperature pattern is strongly predictive of ovulation. Nevertheless, although this test has the advantage of being inexpensive, it is insensitive in many women.
  • • Basal body temperature (BBT) charting has long been used to identify ovulation.
  • • This test requires that a woman’s morning oral temperature be graphically charted
  • • Oral temperatures are usually 97.0° to 98.0°F during the follicular phase.
  • • A postovulatory rise in progesterone levels increases basal temperature by approximately 0.4° to 0.8°F.
  • • postovulatory
  • • This biphasic temperature pattern is strongly predictive of ovulation.
  • • Nevertheless, although this test has the advantage of being inexpensive, it is insensitive in many women.
  • • Let's examine each statement:
  • • Let's examine each statement:
  • • Option A. It can be an insensitive test in many women : This is true. The temperature shift indicating ovulation can be subtle and easy to miss, and factors like illness, sleep disturbances, and lifestyle factors can affect temperature readings.
  • • Option A.
  • • It can be an insensitive test in many women
  • • Option B. With ovulation, the temperature rises roughly 0.8°F : This is generally true. After ovulation, the release of progesterone causes a woman's basal body temperature to rise by approximately 0.4 to 0.8 degrees Fahrenheit. However, the exact increase can vary from woman to woman.
  • • Option B.
  • • With ovulation, the temperature rises roughly 0.8°F
  • • Option C. It is an inexpensive and easy test for ovulation monitoring : This is true. BBT charting is a cost-effective, non-invasive method of possibly determining ovulation. It requires only a thermometer and consistent daily temperature recording upon waking.
  • • Option C.
  • • It is an inexpensive and easy test for ovulation monitoring
  • • Option D . Once the temperature rises, a patient should expect ovulation in the next 12 hours (Least Likely True): This statement is incorrect. In fact, a rise in BBT typically occurs after ovulation. By the time a woman notices a temperature rise, ovulation has likely already occurred, not that it will occur in the next 12 hours.
  • • Option D
  • • Once the temperature rises, a patient should expect ovulation in the next 12 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 435, Wiliams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following is true of luteal phase deficiency?

options.label: A
options.text: It affects approximately 50% of menstrual cycles

options.label: B
options.text: It is seen when the follicular phase is shorter than 14 days

options.label: C
options.text: Fertile women have the same incidence of luteal phase deficiency as infertile women

options.label: D
options.text: It is determined by histologic analysis of the endometrium and defined by a greater than 4-day discrepancy between the specimen-derived cycle date and the actual menstrual cycle day

questions.correct_answer: C. Fertile women have the same incidence of luteal phase deficiency as infertile women
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fertile women have the same incidence of luteal phase deficiency as infertile women

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • LPD is a clinical diagnosis and may be present with a luteal phase ≤10 days in length. Abnormal luteal function may occur as the result of several medical conditions. True isolated LPD implies an underlying pathologic abnormality of the luteal phase in the absence of an identifiable disease process negatively affecting normal LH support of the corpus luteum. No diagnostic test for LPD has proven to be reliable in the clinical setting or in differentiating fertile from infertile women. Endometrial biopsies (lag of > 2 days) only have the precision to distinguish the early luteal, midluteal, and late luteal phases, and have been shown to not discriminate between fertile and infertile women.
  • • LPD is a clinical diagnosis and may be present with a luteal phase ≤10 days in length.
  • • Abnormal luteal function may occur as the result of several medical conditions.
  • • True isolated LPD implies an underlying pathologic abnormality of the luteal phase in the absence of an identifiable disease process negatively affecting normal LH support of the corpus luteum.
  • • No diagnostic test for LPD has proven to be reliable in the clinical setting or in differentiating fertile from infertile women.
  • • Endometrial biopsies (lag of > 2 days) only have the precision to distinguish the early luteal, midluteal, and late luteal phases, and have been shown to not discriminate between fertile and infertile women.
  • • Let's evaluate each statement:
  • • Let's evaluate each statement:
  • • Option A. It affects approximately 50% of menstrual cycles : This is not accurate. LPD does not affect such a high percentage of menstrual cycles. It is considered relatively less common and not observed in half of all menstrual cycles.
  • • Option A.
  • • It affects approximately 50% of menstrual cycles
  • • Option B. It is seen when the follicular phase is shorter than 14 days : LPD is related to the luteal phase, not the follicular phase. LPD is characterized by a luteal phase that is typically shorter than normal (less than about 10 days) or functionally inadequate.
  • • Option B.
  • • It is seen when the follicular phase is shorter than 14 days
  • • Option C. Fertile women have the same incidence of luteal phase deficiency as infertile women (Correct Answer): Recent studies and reviews suggest that the incidence of LPD is similar in both fertile and infertile women. This challenges previous notions that LPD is a common cause of infertility. It's now understood that the diagnostic criteria for LPD may be overly broad, and the condition might not be as directly linked to infertility as once thought.
  • • Option C.
  • • Fertile women have the same incidence of luteal phase deficiency as infertile women
  • • Option D. It is determined by histologic analysis of the endometrium and defined by a greater than 4-day discrepancy between the specimen-derived cycle date and the actual menstrual cycle day : This was the traditional method of diagnosing LPD, based on endometrial biopsy findings. However, the reliability of this diagnostic criterion has been questioned in recent years.
  • • Option D.
  • • It is determined by histologic analysis of the endometrium and defined by a greater than 4-day discrepancy between the specimen-derived cycle date and the actual menstrual cycle day

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 434, Wiliams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 434, Wiliams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: At the onset of puberty, what is the estimated number of follicles in a woman’s ovaries?
questions.explanation:
Ans.D) 300 thousand

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • At the onset of puberty, a woman has about 300,000 to 400,000 follicles remaining in her ovaries. This number represents a significant reduction from the count at birth due to ongoing follicular atresia.

questions.text: What is your interpretation of the following hysterosalpingogram?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Submucosal fibroid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This HSG shows a large well defined lesion in the uterus. This is most likely a submucosal fibroid
  • • This HSG shows a large well defined lesion in the uterus.
  • • This is most likely a submucosal fibroid
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A. Normal : A normal HSG would show a regular, symmetrically shaped uterine cavity without any filling defects or irregularities. The fallopian tubes would be visible, with the contrast material flowing freely through them, indicating patency . No obstructions or unusual shapes should be present.
  • • Option A.
  • • Normal
  • • Option B . Asherman syndrome : This condition is characterized by the presence of intrauterine adhesions or scar tissue. On an HSG, Asherman syndrome may present as irregular filling defects within the uterine cavity or as a generally diminished size of the uterine cavity, depending on the severity of the adhesions.
  • • Option B
  • • Asherman syndrome
  • • Option C. Bilateral tubal block (B/l tubal block) : In cases of bilateral tubal blockage, an HSG would show a lack of contrast material passing through one or both fallopian tubes ie. absence of free spill.
  • • Option C.
  • • Bilateral tubal block (B/l tubal block)
  • • Option D. Submucosal fibroid : They are fibroids that grow just beneath the lining of the uterine cavity. On an HSG, these would appear as filling defects within the uterine cavity. They might show as smooth, round, or lobulated contours projecting into the cavity, disrupting the otherwise smooth and regular shape of the uterus.
  • • Option D.
  • • Submucosal fibroid

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard technique for tubal evaluation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic evaluation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The following are tests done for tubal patency
  • • HSG (usually a preliminary test) Laparoscopic Chromotubation (Gold standard) Saline salpingography (better for intra uterine lesions) Others HyCoSy Falloposcopy
  • • HSG (usually a preliminary test)
  • • Laparoscopic Chromotubation (Gold standard)
  • • Saline salpingography (better for intra uterine lesions)
  • • Others HyCoSy Falloposcopy
  • • HyCoSy Falloposcopy
  • • HyCoSy
  • • Falloposcopy
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Option A. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) : This is a radiographic technique where a contrast dye is injected into the uterine cavity, and X-ray images are taken to visualize the uterus and fallopian tubes. HSG is primarily used for evaluating the internal shape of the uterus and the patency of the fallopian tubes. While it's a commonly used first-line investigation for tubal assessment in infertility evaluations, it provides limited information about the external contour of the tubes and surrounding structures.
  • • Option A.
  • • Hysterosalpingography (HSG)
  • • Option B. Laparoscopic Evaluation : Laparoscopy is considered the gold standard for tubal evaluation. It's a minimally invasive surgical procedure that provides a direct view of the pelvic organs, including the fallopian tubes. Laparoscopy not only allows for the assessment of tubal patency (often combined with chromopertubation, where a dye is passed through the tubes) but also enables visualization of the outer aspects of the tubes and the detection of other pelvic pathologies like endometriosis, adhesions, or fibroids that might affect tubal function. Its main limitation is that it's an invasive procedure requiring anesthesia.
  • • Option B.
  • • Laparoscopic Evaluation
  • • Option C . Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS) : SIS involves the infusion of saline into the uterine cavity during ultrasound examination. This technique can be used to asses tubal patency, it also enhances the visualization of the uterine cavity and can be useful in detecting abnormalities like polyps or fibroids.
  • • Option C
  • • Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS)
  • • Option D. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) : MRI can provide detailed images of the pelvic organs, including the uterus and fallopian tubes, without using ionizing radiation. It's particularly useful in assessing uterine anomalies and some types of fibroids. However, MRI is less commonly used for direct assessment of tubal patency or minor tubal abnormalities compared to laparoscopy or HSG.
  • • Option D.
  • • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Page 441, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Page 441, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: In treating hypertension, with beta blockers, which of the following semen parameter abnormalities may be seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Low semen volume

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Low semen volume often simply reflects incomplete specimen collection or short abstinence interval. However, it may indicate partial vas deferens obstruction or retrograde ejaculation. Partial or complete vas deferens obstruction may be caused by infection, tumor, prior testicular or inguinal surgery, or trauma. Retrograde ejaculation follows failed closure of the bladder neck during ejaculation and allows seminal fluid to flow backward into the bladder. Retrograde ejaculation is suspected in men with Diabetes mellitus Spinal cord damage Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves Medications (β-blockers)
  • • Low semen volume often simply reflects incomplete specimen collection or short abstinence interval.
  • • However, it may indicate partial vas deferens obstruction or retrograde ejaculation. Partial or complete vas deferens obstruction may be caused by infection, tumor, prior testicular or inguinal surgery, or trauma. Retrograde ejaculation follows failed closure of the bladder neck during ejaculation and allows seminal fluid to flow backward into the bladder. Retrograde ejaculation is suspected in men with Diabetes mellitus Spinal cord damage Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves Medications (β-blockers)
  • • Partial or complete vas deferens obstruction may be caused by infection, tumor, prior testicular or inguinal surgery, or trauma. Retrograde ejaculation follows failed closure of the bladder neck during ejaculation and allows seminal fluid to flow backward into the bladder. Retrograde ejaculation is suspected in men with Diabetes mellitus Spinal cord damage Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves Medications (β-blockers)
  • • Partial or complete vas deferens obstruction may be caused by infection, tumor, prior testicular or inguinal surgery, or trauma.
  • • Retrograde ejaculation follows failed closure of the bladder neck during ejaculation and allows seminal fluid to flow backward into the bladder. Retrograde ejaculation is suspected in men with Diabetes mellitus Spinal cord damage Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves Medications (β-blockers)
  • • Diabetes mellitus Spinal cord damage Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves Medications (β-blockers)
  • • Diabetes mellitus
  • • Spinal cord damage
  • • Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves
  • • Medications (β-blockers)
  • • A postejaculatory urinalysis can detect sperm in the bladder and confirm the diagnosis. If urine is properly alkalinized, these sperm are viable and can be retrieved to achieve pregnancy
  • • Let us explore the options given:
  • • Let us explore the options given:
  • • Option A. Azoospermia : This refers to the complete absence of sperm in the semen. While certain medications and health conditions can lead to azoospermia, beta-blockers are not typically associated with this severe a level of spermatogenic failure.
  • • Option A.
  • • Azoospermia
  • • Option B. Oligospermia : Oligospermia means a lower than normal sperm count. Some medications and health issues can lead to oligospermia, but beta-blockers are not commonly linked to significant decreases in sperm count.
  • • Option B.
  • • Oligospermia
  • • Option C. Teratospermia : Teratospermia is characterized by a high percentage of abnormally shaped sperm in the semen. This condition can be caused by various factors, including genetic defects, lifestyle choices, and exposure to certain chemicals or radiation. Beta-blockers are not known to specifically cause teratospermia.
  • • Option C.
  • • Teratospermia
  • • Option D. Low semen volume (Correct Answer): Beta-blockers can lead to a decrease in semen volume. This effect is thought to be related to the general inhibitory effects of beta-blockers on the sympathetic nervous system, which plays a role in seminal emission. As a result, men taking beta-blockers may experience a reduction in the volume of ejaculate.
  • • Option D.
  • • Low semen volume

questions.text: Asthenospermia refers to which of the following semen abnormalities?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sperm motility

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Let's go through each option:
  • • Let's go through each option:
  • • Option A. Sperm Count : This refers to the concentration of sperm in a given volume of ejaculate. When the sperm count is lower than normal, it is termed oligospermia. Asthenospermia is not related to the count or concentration of sperm.
  • • Option A.
  • • Sperm Count
  • • Option B. Semen Volume : This is the total volume of the ejaculated fluid. A low semen volume can be due to various causes, including hormonal imbalances or blockages in the reproductive tract. However, asthenospermia does not pertain to the volume of semen.
  • • Option B.
  • • Semen Volume
  • • Option C. Sperm Motility (Correct Answer): Asthenospermia is specifically related to sperm motility, which refers to the ability of sperm to move efficiently. This is an important factor in fertility since sperm must be able to swim through the female reproductive tract to reach and fertilize the egg. Asthenospermia is characterized by a decreased percentage of motile sperm in the semen.
  • • Option C.
  • • Sperm Motility
  • • Option D. Sperm Morphology : This refers to the size and shape of sperm. Abnormalities in sperm morphology (teratospermia) can impact the ability of sperm to fertilize an egg. Asthenospermia, however, is specifically about the movement ability of sperm, not their shape or size.
  • • Option D.
  • • Sperm Morphology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page 443, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 443, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a test of ovarian reserve?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Day 15 Antral Follicle Count

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tests for ovarian reserve include
  • • Biochemical tests FSH: D2/3: Increased in poor ovarian reserve Estradiol: Day 2: Increased in poor ovarian reserve Inhibin B: Reduced in poor ovarian reserve AMH: Reduced in poor ovarian reserve Ultrasound: Antral follicle count is done on day 2 or 3 of the cycle. The total no of follicles visible are counted. An AFC > 10 is normal. Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test
  • • Biochemical tests FSH: D2/3: Increased in poor ovarian reserve Estradiol: Day 2: Increased in poor ovarian reserve Inhibin B: Reduced in poor ovarian reserve AMH: Reduced in poor ovarian reserve
  • • FSH: D2/3: Increased in poor ovarian reserve Estradiol: Day 2: Increased in poor ovarian reserve Inhibin B: Reduced in poor ovarian reserve AMH: Reduced in poor ovarian reserve
  • • FSH: D2/3: Increased in poor ovarian reserve
  • • Estradiol: Day 2: Increased in poor ovarian reserve
  • • Inhibin B: Reduced in poor ovarian reserve
  • • AMH: Reduced in poor ovarian reserve
  • • Ultrasound: Antral follicle count is done on day 2 or 3 of the cycle. The total no of follicles visible are counted. An AFC > 10 is normal.
  • • Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test
  • • Let's explore each option:
  • • Let's explore each option:
  • • Option A. Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH) : AMH is a hormone produced by the granulosa cells of small ovarian follicles. It is a reliable indicator of a woman's ovarian reserve, as it reflects the number of remaining antral and pre-antral follicles in the ovaries. AMH levels typically decrease with age and lower levels are associated with a diminished ovarian reserve.
  • • Option A.
  • • Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH)
  • • Option B. Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test : This test involves administering clomiphene citrate, a medication that stimulates ovulation, and measuring the response of the ovaries. The response is typically assessed through changes in follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels. Abnormal test results can suggest reduced ovarian reserve.
  • • Option B. Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test
  • • Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test
  • • Option C. Day 2 FSH : This test measures the level of FSH in a woman's blood on the second day of her menstrual cycle. FSH is a hormone that stimulates the ovaries to produce eggs. Elevated levels of FSH on day 2 can be indicative of a diminished ovarian reserve, as the body is having to work harder to stimulate the ovaries.
  • • Option C.
  • • Day 2 FSH
  • • Option D . Day 15 Antral Follicle Count (Correct Answer): This is not a standard test for ovarian reserve. The antral follicle count (AFC) is typically performed much earlier in the menstrual cycle, generally on day 2-5. The AFC involves counting the number of antral follicles (small follicles) in the ovaries using ultrasound, which can give an estimate of the remaining egg supply. Performing this count on day 15 would not be standard practice, as this is typically after ovulation has occurred, making it less relevant for assessing ovarian reserve.
  • • Option D
  • • Day 15 Antral Follicle Count

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: Which day of the menstrual cycle should an HSG be done?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Day 8

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • HSG is a test for tubal patency It also delineates the uterine cavity It is best done between Day 5 – 10 (Before ovulation in the post menstrual period) At this time, few intrauterine clots should remain to block tubal outflow or give the false impression of an intrauterine abnormality. Furthermore, a woman theoretically has not ovulated or possibly conceived. For this test, iodinated contrast medium is infused through an instrument (Leech Wilkinson cannula) placed into the uterus. With fluoroscopy, dye is visually followed as it fills the uterine cavity, then the tubal lumen, and finally spills out of the tubal fimbria into the pelvic cavity.
  • • HSG is a test for tubal patency
  • • It also delineates the uterine cavity
  • • It is best done between Day 5 – 10 (Before ovulation in the post menstrual period)
  • • At this time, few intrauterine clots should remain to block tubal outflow or give the false impression of an intrauterine abnormality.
  • • Furthermore, a woman theoretically has not ovulated or possibly conceived.
  • • For this test, iodinated contrast medium is infused through an instrument (Leech Wilkinson cannula) placed into the uterus.
  • • With fluoroscopy, dye is visually followed as it fills the uterine cavity, then the tubal lumen, and finally spills out of the tubal fimbria into the pelvic cavity.

questions.text: An infertile couple is being evaluated for infertility. They are advised to take a post coital test. What is the purpose of this test?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the viability of sperm

options.label: B
options.text: To assess the quality of cervical mucous

options.label: C
options.text: To evaluate the process of ovulation

questions.correct_answer: B. To assess the quality of cervical mucous
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) To assess the quality of cervical mucous

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The postcoital test, also known as the Sims-Huhner test, was used historically to evaluate cervical mucus. There is limited consensus on the definition of a normal test and hence it does not have much utility. In regions where more specific testing is not available, it may provide information regarding cervical mucus, appropriate intercourse practices and sperm motility. Performed a few hours after sexual intercourse During the test, a sample of cervical mucous is collected using a speculum and a small brush and examined under a microscope to assess the quality, quantity and motility of sperm present in the mucus This provides information about the interaction between the sperm and cervical mucus, which is crucial for successful fertilization.
  • • The postcoital test, also known as the Sims-Huhner test, was used historically to evaluate cervical mucus.
  • • There is limited consensus on the definition of a normal test and hence it does not have much utility. In regions where more specific testing is not available, it may provide information regarding cervical mucus, appropriate intercourse practices and sperm motility.
  • • Performed a few hours after sexual intercourse
  • • During the test, a sample of cervical mucous is collected using a speculum and a small brush and examined under a microscope to assess the quality, quantity and motility of sperm present in the mucus
  • • This provides information about the interaction between the sperm and cervical mucus, which is crucial for successful fertilization.
  • • Now, Let's explore each of the given options for its purpose:
  • • Now, Let's explore each of the given options for its purpose:
  • • Option A. To determine the viability of sperm : The test observes how sperm interact with cervical mucus, which encompasses more than just viability.
  • • Option A.
  • • To determine the viability of sperm
  • • Option B. To assess the quality of cervical mucus (Correct Answer): This is the primary purpose of the postcoital test. It evaluates how well sperm can survive and move through the cervical mucus. This is important because cervical mucus changes in consistency and composition throughout the menstrual cycle, and these changes can impact sperm survival and transport. The test is usually conducted close to the time of ovulation when the cervical mucus is most receptive to sperm.
  • • Option B.
  • • To assess the quality of cervical mucus
  • • Option C. To evaluate the process of ovulation : While the timing of the postcoital test is related to ovulation (as it should be performed around the time of ovulation for optimal cervical mucus quality), the test itself does not evaluate ovulation directly.
  • • Option C.
  • • To evaluate the process of ovulation
  • • Option D. To examine the uterine lining : The postcoital test does not assess the uterine lining. Procedures like ultrasound or endometrial biopsy are more relevant for examining the uterine lining.
  • • Option D.
  • • To examine the uterine lining

questions.text: A 32-year woman presents with primary infertility. She has been trying to conceive for over a year with regular unprotected intercourse but has not been successful. On further evaluation, her menstrual cycles are regular with moderate flow and mild dysmenorrhoea and her partner’s semen analysis is normal. A tubal patency test is ordered. Which of the following test is most appropriate in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hysterosalpingography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The initial investigation of choice for tubal patency is an HSG The best investigation for tubal patency is Laparoscopy with chrompertubation
  • • The initial investigation of choice for tubal patency is an HSG
  • • The best investigation for tubal patency is Laparoscopy with chrompertubation
  • • Let's review each of the options provided:
  • • Let's review each of the options provided:
  • • Option A. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) (Correct Answer): HSG is a radiographic procedure where a contrast dye is injected into the uterine cavity and X-ray images are taken. It's often the first-line test for evaluating tubal patency in women with infertility, as it's less invasive than laparoscopy. HSG can reveal whether the fallopian tubes are open and can also provide information about the shape of the uterine cavity. It's particularly suitable in this scenario where there are no other major indications for laparoscopy.
  • • Option A.
  • • Hysterosalpingography (HSG)
  • • Option B. Laparoscopy with Chromopertubation : This is a more invasive procedure. While it's considered the gold standard for evaluating tubal patency, it's typically reserved for cases where HSG results are inconclusive or when there's a suspicion of other pelvic pathology that needs direct visualization, like endometriosis or adhesions.
  • • Option B.
  • • Laparoscopy with Chromopertubation
  • • Option C. Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS) : SIS involves the infusion of saline into the uterine cavity during an ultrasound exam. It's effective for evaluating the uterine cavity for abnormalities like polyps or fibroids but may not be as effective as HSG for assessing tubal patency.
  • • Option C.
  • • Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS)
  • • Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis antibody testing : While testing for Chlamydia trachomatis antibodies can be important in infertility evaluations, particularly if there's a history suggesting a risk of pelvic inflammatory disease, it doesn't directly assess tubal patency. It can be used as an adjunct to other tests when determining the cause of infertility.
  • • Option D.
  • • Chlamydia trachomatis antibody testing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In infertility :
  • ➤ In infertility
  • ➤ The initial investigation of choice for tubal patency is an HSG The best investigation for tubal patency is Laparoscopy with chrompertubation
  • ➤ The initial investigation of choice for tubal patency is an HSG
  • ➤ The best investigation for tubal patency is Laparoscopy with chrompertubation

questions.text: A 29-year woman presents to the Gyn OPD wit her husband. She has been unsuccessfully trying to conceive since 1.5 years. On asking, she reveals that she has irregular menstrual cycles. There is no other significant history. Which of the following is NOT a test for determining if she is ovulation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Urinary FSH

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tests for Ovulation include
  • • History: Regular menstrual cycles; Mittelschmerz, dysmenorrhoea, Premenstrual Syndrome Basal body temperature: Just prior to ovulation, there is a drop in temperature by 0.25, then it rises by 0.5 deg C Cervical mucus study: At the time of ovulation, cervical mucus is thin and stretchy; It is thin and viscous at the time of luteal phase Hormonal Studies: Mid Luteal Progesterone: Peak on Day 21 (> 10 ng/ml) Urinary LH kits Endometrial Biopsy (Secretory phase of the cycle at day 21) Ultrasound:
  • • History: Regular menstrual cycles; Mittelschmerz, dysmenorrhoea, Premenstrual Syndrome
  • • History:
  • • Mittelschmerz,
  • • Premenstrual Syndrome
  • • Basal body temperature: Just prior to ovulation, there is a drop in temperature by 0.25, then it rises by 0.5 deg C
  • • Basal body temperature:
  • • Cervical mucus study: At the time of ovulation, cervical mucus is thin and stretchy; It is thin and viscous at the time of luteal phase
  • • Cervical mucus study:
  • • thin and stretchy;
  • • Hormonal Studies: Mid Luteal Progesterone: Peak on Day 21 (> 10 ng/ml) Urinary LH kits
  • • Hormonal Studies:
  • • Mid Luteal Progesterone: Peak on Day 21 (> 10 ng/ml) Urinary LH kits
  • • Mid Luteal Progesterone: Peak on Day 21 (> 10 ng/ml)
  • • Peak on Day 21
  • • Urinary LH kits
  • • Endometrial Biopsy (Secretory phase of the cycle at day 21)
  • • Endometrial Biopsy
  • • Ultrasound:
  • • Ultrasound:
  • • Trilaminar endometrium seen in the proliferative phase. In the secretory phase, the endometrium becomes homogeneous. Ovary: Shows a dominant follicle at the time of ovulation (18-20 mm)
  • • Trilaminar endometrium seen in the proliferative phase.
  • • In the secretory phase, the endometrium becomes homogeneous.
  • • Ovary: Shows a dominant follicle at the time of ovulation (18-20 mm)
  • • Laparoscopy: If performed mid-cycle, a large follicle may be seen
  • • Laparoscopy: If performed mid-cycle, a large follicle may be seen
  • • Laparoscopy:
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Option A. Day 21 Progesterone : This test is used to confirm ovulation. Progesterone levels rise following ovulation, due to the formation of the corpus luteum. A blood test for progesterone is typically done about 7 days after expected ovulation (around day 21 in a typical 28-day cycle) to check if the levels are high enough to suggest that ovulation has occurred.
  • • Option A.
  • • Day 21 Progesterone
  • • Option B. Pre-menstrual Endometrial Biopsy : This procedure involves taking a small sample of the uterine lining just before menstruation. It's used to check for luteal phase defects. The endometrium undergoes specific changes after ovulation, and analyzing the tissue can help determine if these changes are occurring properly, suggesting that ovulation has taken place.
  • • Option B.
  • • Pre-menstrual Endometrial Biopsy
  • • Option C. Serial Transvaginal Scans : These are ultrasounds done transvaginally at different stages of the menstrual cycle. They can be used to monitor the growth and development of follicles in the ovaries, and to observe the rupture of a follicle (indicative of ovulation). This is a direct metho d to visualize the process of ovulation.
  • • Option C.
  • • Serial Transvaginal Scans
  • • Option D. Urinary FSH (Correct Answer): Urinary FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone) levels are not typically used to determine if ovulation is occurring. FSH is important in the development of follicles in the ovaries, but its level in urine isn't directly correlated with ovulation. Blood levels of FSH are often measured, but usually to assess ovarian reserve rather than to confirm ovulation.
  • • Option D.
  • • Urinary FSH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

  • ➤ Ref: Page 435, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: A 38-year woman marries for the 2 nd time, her 1 st husband having expired. She has a history of a D & C for a missed abortion with her 1 st husband. She now reports to the gyn OPD with complaints of inability to conceive after trying for 1 year. She has regular periods. A pelvic ultrasound is normal. Husband semen analysis is normal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Laparoscopy with chrompertubation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a patient with secondary infertility One of the common causes of secondary infertility is tubal causes following PID Tubal patency needs to be checked in this patient Hence the best option is laparoscopic chrompertubation
  • • This is a patient with secondary infertility
  • • One of the common causes of secondary infertility is tubal causes following PID
  • • Tubal patency needs to be checked in this patient
  • • Hence the best option is laparoscopic chrompertubation
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Option A. Ovulation Induction : This is typically considered when there is evidence of anovulation or irregular ovulation. However, in this case, the patient reports regular menstrual cycles, which suggests that she is likely ovulating normally.
  • • Option A.
  • • Ovulation Induction
  • • Option B. Laparoscopy with Chromopertubation (Correct Answer): Given her history of a prior dilation and curettage (D&C), which can sometimes lead to intrauterine adhesions or other uterine abnormalities, and the fact that other basic fertility evaluations are normal, a laparoscopy with chromopertubation is a reasonable next step. This procedure allows for direct visualization of the pelvic organs and can assess for any adhesions, endometriosis, or other factors that could be contributing to infertility. Chromopertubation during laparoscopy will assess the patency of the fallopian tubes.
  • • Option B.
  • • Laparoscopy with Chromopertubation
  • • Option C. Endometrial Biopsy : This test is used to evaluate the health of the endometrium, often in cases of abnormal uterine bleeding or to assess for luteal phase defects. Given her history and current presentation, an endometrial biopsy might not be the most informative next step in the absence of specific indications for this test.
  • • Option C.
  • • Endometrial Biopsy
  • • Option D. IVF (In Vitro Fertilization) : IVF is a more advanced fertility treatment option and is often considered when other less invasive methods have failed, or when there is a clear indication for its use (such as blocked fallopian tubes, severe male factor infertility, etc.). Jumping straight to IVF without first assessing for other potential issues (like tubal patency or intrauterine adhesions) may be premature in this scenario.
  • • Option D.
  • • IVF (In Vitro Fertilization)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The key educational objective here is to understand the stepwise approach in managing infertility, especially in cases with a potentially complicated obstetric history. Initial assessments should include semen analysis, ovulation confirmation, and an evaluation of the uterine cavity and tubal patency.
  • ➤ The key educational objective here is to understand the stepwise approach in managing infertility, especially in cases with a potentially complicated obstetric history.
  • ➤ Initial assessments should include semen analysis, ovulation confirmation, and an evaluation of the uterine cavity and tubal patency.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 430, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 430, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: A 23-year woman is brought to the OPD by her mother-in-law who is very anxious that she hasn’t conceived since her marriage which was 8 months ago. The woman has regular cycles and coital frequency is about 3 times/ week. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Explain fertile period

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • As the woman is young and has no significant history, the best management would be reassurance with advice to follow up after 4 more months if she doesn’t conceive. Evaluation for infertility is started after 1 year of unprotected intercourse or earlier if the woman is > 35 years or has irregular cycles.
  • • As the woman is young and has no significant history, the best management would be reassurance with advice to follow up after 4 more months if she doesn’t conceive.
  • • Evaluation for infertility is started after 1 year of unprotected intercourse or earlier if the woman is > 35 years or has irregular cycles.
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Option A. Pelvic Ultrasound : This imaging test can be useful to assess the uterus and ovaries for any structural abnormalities. However, without any specific symptoms or history suggesting a problem (such as irregular periods, pain, or a history of pelvic disease), jumping to a pelvic ultrasound might be premature at this stage.
  • • Option A.
  • • Pelvic Ultrasound
  • • Option B. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) : HSG is used to evaluate the uterine cavity and the patency of the fallopian tubes. While it's an important test in the fertility workup, it's usually not the first step, especially in a young woman without a significant duration of infertility (generally considered to be one year of trying without conception for women under 35).
  • • Option B.
  • • Hysterosalpingography (HSG)
  • • Option C. Examination of Male Partner : Male factor infertility contributes to around half of all infertility cases. However, starting with the examination of the male partner without first addressing potential misunderstandings about the timing of intercourse relative to the fertile window may not be the most efficient first step.
  • • Option C.
  • • Examination of Male Partner
  • • Option D. Explain Fertile Period (Correct Answer): Since the couple has only been trying to conceive for 8 months, and the woman has regular cycles and there are no immediate indications of infertility, the most appropriate next step is to ensure that they have accurate information about the fertile window in the menstrual cycle. Understanding the timing of ovulation and the days during which conception is most likely can significantly increase the chances of natural conception.
  • • Option D.
  • • Explain Fertile Period

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Before proceeding any investigations, it's crucial to ensure that couples are aware of the most fertile period in the menstrual cycle, typically the days leading up to and including the day of ovulation. This knowledge is fundamental for any couple trying to conceive and is especially pertinent when the duration of trying is less than a year and there are no obvious symptoms or history suggesting infertility.
  • ➤ Before proceeding any investigations, it's crucial to ensure that couples are aware of the most fertile period in the menstrual cycle, typically the days leading up to and including the day of ovulation.
  • ➤ This knowledge is fundamental for any couple trying to conceive and is especially pertinent when the duration of trying is less than a year and there are no obvious symptoms or history suggesting infertility.
  • ➤ ReF: Page no 430, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ ReF: Page no 430, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following medications is used for achieving a pregnancy in a patient with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gonadotropins

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism, the cause of anovulation is in the pituitary or hypothalamus. Hence ovulation can be achieved by use of gonadotropins (FSH or LH) In ovarian causes of anovulation lie PCOS, clomiphene citrate and letrozole is used Estradiol is not an ovulation inducing agent
  • • In Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism, the cause of anovulation is in the pituitary or hypothalamus.
  • • Hence ovulation can be achieved by use of gonadotropins (FSH or LH)
  • • In ovarian causes of anovulation lie PCOS, clomiphene citrate and letrozole is used
  • • Estradiol is not an ovulation inducing agent
  • • Let's review each of the options provided:
  • • Let's review each of the options provided:
  • • Option A. Estradiol : Estradiol plays a crucial role in the menstrual cycle and is used in various hormonal therapies, it is not primarily used to induce ovulation.
  • • Option A.
  • • Estradiol
  • • Option B. Letrozole : Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor that's often used for ovulation induction, particularly in cases of polycystic ovary syndrome .It works by reducing estrogen levels, which in turn stimulates the release of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), promoting ovulation. However, it's not the primary choice for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.
  • • Option B.
  • • Letrozole
  • • hypogonadism.
  • • Option C. Gonadotropins (Correct Answer): Gonadotropins, which include FSH and LH, are the primary treatment for hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This condition is characterized by low levels of these hormones due to problems in the hypothalamus or pituitary gland. Administering gonadotropins directly stimulates the ovaries to produce eggs, making it the most effective treatment for inducing ovulation in women with this condition.
  • • Option C.
  • • Gonadotropins
  • • Option D. Clomiphene Citrate (Clomid) : Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used commonly to induce ovulation in women with certain types of infertility, particularly when the issue is anovulation or oligoovulation. Clomiphene works by blocking estrogen receptors, which increases the release of FSH and LH. However, in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, where FSH and LH are deficient, clomiphene is not typically effective .
  • • Option D.
  • • Clomiphene Citrate (Clomid)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page 481, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 481, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old obese female who is seeking pregnancy is recently diagnosed with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Which of the following should be recommended as first-line management for her anovulation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Letrozole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • All the options mentioned will help in ovulation in PCOS Lifestyle management (Weight loss if BMI is high + exercise) is the PRIMARY mode of management The 1 st line ovulation induction agents are Letrozole Clomiphene citrate Amongst these 2, the recent ESHRE guidelines says that Letrozole is to be preferred over clomiphene in PCOS. Gonadotropins may be used as second line agents for ovulation induction after oral drugs. Insulin sensitizing agents such as metformin and myoinositol are also used in PCOS patients as adjunctive treatment.
  • • All the options mentioned will help in ovulation in PCOS
  • • Lifestyle management (Weight loss if BMI is high + exercise) is the PRIMARY mode of management
  • • The 1 st line ovulation induction agents are Letrozole Clomiphene citrate
  • • Letrozole Clomiphene citrate
  • • Letrozole
  • • Clomiphene citrate
  • • Amongst these 2, the recent ESHRE guidelines says that Letrozole is to be preferred over clomiphene in PCOS.
  • • Gonadotropins may be used as second line agents for ovulation induction after oral drugs. Insulin sensitizing agents such as metformin and myoinositol are also used in PCOS patients as adjunctive treatment.
  • • Let's review each option separately:
  • • Let's review each option separately:
  • • Option A. Gonadotropins : These are injectable hormones (FSH and LH) used to stimulate ovulation. While effective, they are typically not the first line of treatment for PCOS due to the increased risk of multiple pregnancies and ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. They are often considered when other treatments have failed.
  • • Option A.
  • • Gonadotropins
  • • Option B. Clomiphene Citrate : This is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that has traditionally been used as the first-line treatment for inducing ovulation in women with PCOS. It works by blocking estrogen receptors in the brain, which increases the release of FSH and LH, thereby stimulating ovulation.
  • • Option B.
  • • Clomiphene Citrate
  • • Option C. Letrozole (Correct Answer): Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, has recently become preferred over clomiphene citrate for the first-line management of anovulation in women with PCOS, particularly in obese patients. Studies have shown that letrozole is more effective in inducing ovulation in women with PCOS.
  • • Option C.
  • • Letrozole
  • • Option D. Insulin-Sensitizing Agents : These agents, such as metformin, are used to improve insulin resistance, a common feature in PCOS. While they can help in regulating menstrual cycles and improving the efficacy of ovulation-inducing agents, they are generally not used as a standalone first-line treatment
  • • Option D.
  • • Insulin-Sensitizing Agents

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Letrozole has emerged as a preferred first-line treatment due to its higher efficacy in inducing ovulation and also due to mono-follicular development compared to clomiphene citrate, especially in obese patients with PCOS.
  • ➤ Letrozole has emerged as a preferred first-line treatment due to its higher efficacy in inducing ovulation and also due to mono-follicular development compared to clomiphene citrate, especially in obese patients with PCOS.
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.eshre.eu/Guidelines-and-Legal/Guidelines/Polycystic-Ovary-Syndrome
  • ➤ Ref:

questions.text: In women with hyperprolactinemia caused by a pituitary micro-prolactinoma, which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgical therapy is preferred over medical therapy.

options.label: B
options.text: During pregnancy, cabergoline is preferred over bromocriptine.

options.label: C
options.text: Clomiphene citrate may be ineffective for ovulation induction.

options.label: D
options.text: Dopamine-agonist therapy should be increased once pregnancy is achieved.

questions.correct_answer: C. Clomiphene citrate may be ineffective for ovulation induction.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Clomiphene citrate may be ineffective for ovulation induction.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • If hyperprolactinemia is found, then physiologic, pharmacologic, or other secondary causes of hormone hypersecretion are sought Dopamine agonists are the primary treatment of hyperprolactinemia. Surgical therapies are only considered with prolactin-secreting adenomas resistant to medical therapy. During pregnancy, if hyperprolactinemia is not associated with a pituitary lesion or a lesion is less than 10 mm (microadenoma), then dopamine-agonist therapy is stopped because the tumor expansion risk is low Bromocriptine is preferred in pregnancy.
  • • If hyperprolactinemia is found, then physiologic, pharmacologic, or other secondary causes of hormone hypersecretion are sought
  • • Dopamine agonists are the primary treatment of hyperprolactinemia.
  • • Surgical therapies are only considered with prolactin-secreting adenomas resistant to medical therapy.
  • • During pregnancy, if hyperprolactinemia is not associated with a pituitary lesion or a lesion is less than 10 mm (microadenoma), then dopamine-agonist therapy is stopped because the tumor expansion risk is low
  • • Bromocriptine is preferred in pregnancy.
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Option A. Surgical therapy is preferred over medical therapy : This is generally not true. Medical therapy, typically with dopamine agonists like bromocriptine or cabergoline, is the first-line treatment for hyperprolactinemia, including that caused by micro-prolactinomas. These medications are effective in reducing prolactin levels and often lead to tumor shrinkage. Surgical therapy is usually reserved for cases where medical therapy is ineffective or not tolerated.
  • • Option A.
  • • Surgical therapy is preferred over medical therapy
  • • Option B. During pregnancy, cabergoline is preferred over bromocriptine : Actually, bromocriptine is generally preferred over cabergoline during pregnancy. Bromocriptine has a longer track record and more data supporting its safety in pregnancy
  • • Option B.
  • • During pregnancy, cabergoline is preferred over bromocriptine
  • • Option C. Clomiphene citrate may be ineffective for ovulation induction (Correct Answer): This is true. Clomiphene citrate is an ovulation induction agent that works by blocking estrogen receptors, leading to an increase in the release of FSH and LH. However, in the presence of elevated prolactin levels, as seen in hyperprolactinemia, the effectiveness of clomiphene may be diminished. Therefore, normalizing prolactin levels with dopamine agonists is often necessary before or in conjunction with using clomiphene.
  • • Option C.
  • • Clomiphene citrate may be ineffective for ovulation induction
  • • Option D. Dopamine-agonist therapy should be increased once pregnancy is achieved : This is not typically recommended. In fact, dopamine agonist therapy is often discontinued once pregnancy is confirmed in women with micro-prolactinomas. This is because the risk of tumor growth during pregnancy is low, and the safety of continued use of these drugs during pregnancy is not fully established.
  • • Option D.
  • • Dopamine-agonist therapy should be increased once pregnancy is achieved

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ First-line treatment of hyper-prolactinemia with a mico-adenoma typically involves medical therapy with dopamine agonists, which are effective in lowering prolactin levels and can restore ovulatory function.
  • ➤ First-line treatment of hyper-prolactinemia with a mico-adenoma typically involves medical therapy with dopamine agonists, which are effective in lowering prolactin levels and can restore ovulatory function.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 450, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 450, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: Compared with clomiphene citrate therapy, gonadotropin therapy has which of the following characteristics?

options.label: D
options.text: Greater negative effect on the endometrium

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Higher ovulation rate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Gonadotropins are usually 2 nd line drugs for ovulation induction They are preferred in hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism They have a higher ovulation rate and a higher multiple pregnancy rate also. Women with PCOS have ovaries highly sensitive to gonadotropin stimulation. They have a higher risk of excessive ovarian response and of multifetal pregnancy than those with normal ovaries. Unlike clomiphene, they do not have a negative effect on the endometrium.
  • • Gonadotropins are usually 2 nd line drugs for ovulation induction
  • • They are preferred in hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism
  • • They have a higher ovulation rate and a higher multiple pregnancy rate also.
  • • Women with PCOS have ovaries highly sensitive to gonadotropin stimulation. They have a higher risk of excessive ovarian response and of multifetal pregnancy than those with normal ovaries.
  • • Unlike clomiphene, they do not have a negative effect on the endometrium.
  • • Let's examine each option separately :
  • • Let's examine each option separately :
  • • Option A. Higher Ovulation Rate (Correct Answer): This is because gonadotropins more directly stimulate the ovaries, whereas clomiphene citrate works indirectly by blocking estrogen receptors, which in turn promotes the release of FSH and LH.
  • • Option A.
  • • Higher Ovulation Rate
  • • Option B . Lower Multiple Pregnancy Rate : This is not true for gonadotropin therapy. In fact, gonadotropin therapy has a higher risk of multiple pregnancies compared to clomiphene citrate. This is due to the more potent and direct ovarian stimulation with gonadotropins, which can lead to the development of multiple follicles.
  • • Option B
  • • Lower Multiple Pregnancy Rate
  • • Option C. Lower Ovarian Hyperstimulation Rate : Gonadotropin therapy actually has a higher risk of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) compared to clomiphene citrate. The ovaries become swollen and painful, and it is more likely with stimulation of the ovaries by gonadotropins.
  • • Option C.
  • • Lower Ovarian Hyperstimulation Rate
  • • Option D. Greater Negative Effect on the Endometrium : Clomiphene citrate, not gonadotropin therapy, is more commonly associated with a negative effect on the endometrium.
  • • Option D.
  • • Greater Negative Effect on the Endometrium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page 479, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 479, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following is LEAST likely to be true regarding clomiphene citrate therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: The typical starting dose is 100 mg.

options.label: B
options.text: It is classified as a category X drug by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

options.label: C
options.text: It can be initiated on the second day of the menstrual cycle.

options.label: D
options.text: Most pregnancies will occur during the first three treatment cycles.

questions.correct_answer: A. The typical starting dose is 100 mg.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The typical starting dose is 100 mg.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Clomiphene citrate is an anti-estrogen It is used in ovulation induction in anovulatory women (PCOS) It is given as a starting dose of 50mg from Day2 to Day 6 followed by an follicular imaging scan from the 10 th day of the period It is contra-indicated in pregnancy (FDA Category X)
  • • Clomiphene citrate is an anti-estrogen
  • • It is used in ovulation induction in anovulatory women (PCOS)
  • • It is given as a starting dose of 50mg from Day2 to Day 6 followed by an follicular imaging scan from the 10 th day of the period
  • • It is contra-indicated in pregnancy (FDA Category X)
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Let's evaluate each option:
  • • Option A. The typical starting dose is 100 mg (Correct Answer): This is the least likely to be true. The typical starting dose of clomiphene citrate is usually 50 mg per day, not 100 mg. The dose may be increased in subsequent cycles if there is no response, but starting at a higher dose increases the risk of side effects, including the chance of multiple pregnancies.
  • • Option A.
  • • The typical starting dose is 100 mg
  • • Option B. It is classified as a category X drug by the FDA : Clomiphene citrate is actually classified as FDA pregnancy category X, meaning that it should not be used during pregnancy. The drug is used to induce ovulation, but if a woman becomes pregnant, the use of clomiphene should be discontinued due to potential risks to the fetus.
  • • Option B.
  • • It is classified as a category X drug by the FDA
  • • Option C. It can be initiated on the second day of the menstrual cycle : This is true. Clomiphene citrate is often initiated on the second, third, fourth, or fifth day of the menstrual cycle.
  • • Option C.
  • • It can be initiated on the second day of the menstrual cycle
  • • Option D. Most pregnancies will occur during the first three treatment cycles : This is true. The majority of pregnancies achieved with clomiphene citrate occur within the first three cycles of treatment. If conception has not occurred after this time, the likelihood of success with continued use of clomiphene decreases, and other treatment options may be considered.
  • • Option D.
  • • Most pregnancies will occur during the first three treatment cycles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page 450, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 450, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: A 38-year-old with infertility secondary to tubal blockage just underwent in vitro fertilization (IVF). Her peak estradiol was 4500 pg/mL. Seventeen oocytes were retrieved, and two embryos were transferred. She conceived with a singleton gestation. She developed ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. Which of the following was a predisposing factor in developing ovarian hyperstimulation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Estradiol level

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Risk factors for OHSS include
  • • Young age (< 35y) Low BMI PCOS History of allergy/ atopy High serum estradiol Previous h/o OHSS Multiple follicles (PCOS) High dose/ repeated doses of hCG Pregnancy
  • • Young age (< 35y)
  • • Low BMI
  • • PCOS
  • • History of allergy/ atopy
  • • High serum estradiol
  • • Previous h/o OHSS
  • • Multiple follicles (PCOS)
  • • High dose/ repeated doses of hCG
  • • Pregnancy
  • • Let's examine each option in relation to the predisposition to OHSS:
  • • Let's examine each option in relation to the predisposition to OHSS:
  • • Option A . Her Age : While age can impact various aspects of fertility and responses to fertility treatments, it is not typically considered a direct predisposing factor for the development of OHSS. Women of varying ages can develop OHSS, and it's more related to the response to the ovarian stimulation rather than age per se.
  • • Option A
  • • Her Age
  • • Option B. Estradiol Level (Correct Answer): A high estradiol level is indeed a key predisposing factor for OHSS. A peak estradiol level of 4500 pg/mL, as mentioned in the scenario, is significantly high and can be associated with an increased risk of developing OHSS. This is due to the large number of growing follicles producing estradiol, which can lead to increased vascular permeability and the symptoms associated with OHSS.
  • • Option B.
  • • Estradiol Level
  • • Option C. Etiology of Her Infertility : The underlying cause of infertility (in this case, tubal blockage) is generally not a direct risk factor for OHSS
  • • Option C.
  • • Etiology of Her Infertility
  • • Option D. Number of Embryos Transferred : The number of embryos transferred does not directly predispose to OHSS. OHSS is related to the ovarian response to stimulation during the IVF cycle, not the embryo transfer process
  • • Option D.
  • • Number of Embryos Transferred

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 456, Williams Gynecology 3 rd editio
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 456, Williams Gynecology 3 rd editio

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is thought to play a major role in ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Human chorionic gonadotropin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • OHSS is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation. It occurs mostly in IVF due to controlled ovarian hyperstimulation (COH) but can also happen with simple ovulation induction It is an iatrogenic and potentially a life-threatening complication of COH hCG and VEGF have been implicated in the etiology of OHSS
  • • OHSS is characterized by multiple follicular development and ovarian enlargement following hCG stimulation.
  • • It occurs mostly in IVF due to controlled ovarian hyperstimulation (COH) but can also happen with simple ovulation induction
  • • It is an iatrogenic and potentially a life-threatening complication of COH
  • • hCG and VEGF have been implicated in the etiology of OHSS
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Option A. Progesterone : Progesterone is a hormone produced by the corpus luteum after ovulation and during pregnancy. While it plays a critical role in the menstrual cycle and maintaining pregnancy, it is not primarily implicated in the development of OHSS.
  • • Option A.
  • • Progesterone
  • • Option B. Luteinizing Hormone (LH) : LH is involved in the natural ovulation process. It triggers ovulation and the development of the corpus luteum. While controlled ovarian hyperstimulation often involves drugs that mimic LH action, LH itself is not the primary hormone implicated in OHSS.
  • • Option B.
  • • Luteinizing Hormone (LH)
  • • Option C. Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) (Correct Answer): hCG is the hormone primarily implicated in OHSS. In fertility treatments, hCG is often used to mimic the natural LH surge to trigger ovulation. However, its use, especially in high doses or in sensitive individuals, can lead to OHSS. hCG stimulates the ovaries to produce more estrogen, leading to ovarian enlargement and increased vascular permeability, which are key features of OHSS.
  • • Option C.
  • • Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG)
  • • Option D. Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) : FSH is used in fertility treatments to stimulate the development of ovarian follicles. While it plays a role in controlled ovarian hyperstimulation, it is not directly responsible for the development of OHSS.
  • • Option D.
  • • Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page 456, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 456, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: If concern for ovarian hyperstimulation is present during ovulation induction, which of the following can be used to induce the endogenous luteinizing hormone (LH) surge?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • OHSS can be prevented by the following ways:
  • • Use of GnRH antagonists (instead of GnRH agonists) for down regulation Low starting dose of gonadotropins in high-risk women Metformin cotreatment during gonadotropin stimulation in women with PCOS or at high risk of OHSS Close monitoring of the superovulation cycles using TVS and serum estradiol estimation Replacing hCG with leuprolide (GnRH agonist) as a maturation trigger (i.e. induce the LH surge) To withhold ovulatory dose of hCG in susceptible cases and to cancel the cycle or to delay the dose of hCG injection (coasting) Cryopreservation of oocytes or embryos for future use Aspiration of immature oocytes and in vitro maturation (IVM) Progesterone should be used for luteal phase support instead of hCG Cabergoline and albumin have a role in reducing the incidence of OHSS in those at high risk
  • • Use of GnRH antagonists (instead of GnRH agonists) for down regulation
  • • Low starting dose of gonadotropins in high-risk women
  • • Metformin cotreatment during gonadotropin stimulation in women with PCOS or at high risk of OHSS
  • • Close monitoring of the superovulation cycles using TVS and serum estradiol estimation
  • • Replacing hCG with leuprolide (GnRH agonist) as a maturation trigger (i.e. induce the LH surge)
  • • To withhold ovulatory dose of hCG in susceptible cases and to cancel the cycle or to delay the dose of hCG injection (coasting)
  • • Cryopreservation of oocytes or embryos for future use
  • • Aspiration of immature oocytes and in vitro maturation (IVM)
  • • Progesterone should be used for luteal phase support instead of hCG
  • • Cabergoline and albumin have a role in reducing the incidence of OHSS in those at high risk
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Option A. Urinary Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) : This is commonly used to induce ovulation, as it acts like the body's natural luteinizing hormone (LH) surge. However, hCG can increase the risk of OHSS, especially in patients who are overly responsive to ovarian stimulation.
  • • Option A.
  • • Urinary Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG)
  • • Option B. Recombinant Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) : Similar to urinary hCG, recombinant hCG is used to induce ovulation but can also contribute to the development of OHSS. Both forms of hCG have a longer duration of action, which can exacerbate OHSS in high-risk patients.
  • • Option B.
  • • Recombinant Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG)
  • • Option C. Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) Agonist (Correct Answer): In patients at risk for OHSS, a GnRH agonist can be used to trigger ovulation. Unlike hCG, GnRH agonists cause a shorter and more physiologic LH surge, which can induce ovulation with a lower risk of OHSS. This is particularly beneficial in patients undergoing controlled ovarian stimulation as part of an IVF cycle who have a high number of follicles.
  • • Option C.
  • • Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) Agonist
  • • Option D. Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) Antagonist : GnRH antagonists are used during ovarian stimulation protocols to prevent premature ovulation. They do not trigger the LH surge.
  • • Option D.
  • • Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) Antagonist

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page 456, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 456, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following infertility scenarios would warrant intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI)?

options.label: B
options.text: Infertility secondary to diminished ovarian reserve

options.label: C
options.text: Infertility secondary to bilateral distal fallopian tube occlusion

options.label: D
options.text: Infertility secondary to the male partner’s severe oligospermia

questions.correct_answer: D. Infertility secondary to the male partner’s severe oligospermia
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Infertility secondary to the male partner’s severe oligospermia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • ICSI is intra cytoplasmic sperm injection It is a variation of IVF and is most applicable to male actor infertility. During the micromanipulation technique of ICSI, cumulus cells surrounding an ovum are enzymatically digested, and a single sperm is directly injected through the zona pellucida and oocyte cell membrane. Pregnancy rates with ICSI are comparable with those achieved with IVF or other causes of infertility.
  • • ICSI is intra cytoplasmic sperm injection
  • • It is a variation of IVF and is most applicable to male actor infertility.
  • • During the micromanipulation technique of ICSI, cumulus cells surrounding an ovum are enzymatically digested, and a single sperm is directly injected through the zona pellucida and oocyte cell membrane.
  • • Pregnancy rates with ICSI are comparable with those achieved with IVF or other causes of infertility.
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Option A. Infertility secondary to Anovulation : Anovulation, the absence of ovulation, is often treated with medications that induce ovulation, such as clomiphene citrate or gonadotropins. ICSI is not typically indicated in cases where the primary issue is anovulation, as the main challenge is to produce a viable egg, not the fertilization process itself.
  • • Option A.
  • • Infertility secondary to Anovulation
  • • Option B. Infertility secondary to Diminished Ovarian Reserve : While IVF may be recommended in such cases to maximize the chance of fertilization, ICSI is not necessarily indicated unless there is also a concurrent male factor infertility.
  • • Option B.
  • • Infertility secondary to Diminished Ovarian Reserve
  • • Option C. Infertility secondary to Bilateral Distal Fallopian Tube Occlusion : When the fallopian tubes are blocked, particularly at the distal end (farther from the uterus), IVF is the usual treatment of choice because it bypasses the fallopian tubes altogether. ICSI may be added if there is an additional factor of male infertility.
  • • Option C.
  • • Infertility secondary to Bilateral Distal Fallopian Tube Occlusion
  • • Option D. Infertility secondary to the Male Partner’s Severe Oligospermia (Correct Answer): Severe oligospermia, characterized by a very low sperm count, is a classic indication for ICSI. In such cases, the chances of sperm naturally fertilizing an egg are significantly reduced. ICSI addresses this by directly injecting a single sperm into the egg, thus bypassing the need for a large number of motile sperm.
  • • Option D.
  • • Infertility secondary to the Male Partner’s Severe Oligospermia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ ReF: Page 465, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ ReF: Page 465, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following assisted reproductive technologies (ART) techniques is shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Embryo biopsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is an image showing embryo biopsy which is done in pre-implantation genetic diagnosis During this technique, cells are removed from a developing embryo. Multiple options exist regarding biopsy timing and genetic material source. Biopsy of the first and second polar body has the advantage of avoiding cell removal from the developing embryo, but the disadvantage is that genetic abnormalities of paternal origin are not detected. Biopsy of cleavage-stage embryos (6- to 8-cell stage) allows evaluation of both maternal and paternal contribution to the genome Biopsy of tropho-ectoderm at the blastocyst stage
  • • This is an image showing embryo biopsy which is done in pre-implantation genetic diagnosis
  • • During this technique, cells are removed from a developing embryo.
  • • Multiple options exist regarding biopsy timing and genetic material source. Biopsy of the first and second polar body has the advantage of avoiding cell removal from the developing embryo, but the disadvantage is that genetic abnormalities of paternal origin are not detected. Biopsy of cleavage-stage embryos (6- to 8-cell stage) allows evaluation of both maternal and paternal contribution to the genome Biopsy of tropho-ectoderm at the blastocyst stage
  • • Biopsy of the first and second polar body has the advantage of avoiding cell removal from the developing embryo, but the disadvantage is that genetic abnormalities of paternal origin are not detected. Biopsy of cleavage-stage embryos (6- to 8-cell stage) allows evaluation of both maternal and paternal contribution to the genome Biopsy of tropho-ectoderm at the blastocyst stage
  • • Biopsy of the first and second polar body has the advantage of avoiding cell removal from the developing embryo, but the disadvantage is that genetic abnormalities of paternal origin are not detected.
  • • Biopsy of cleavage-stage embryos (6- to 8-cell stage) allows evaluation of both maternal and paternal contribution to the genome
  • • Biopsy of tropho-ectoderm at the blastocyst stage
  • • Let us look at each option separately:
  • • Let us look at each option separately:
  • • Option A. Embryo Biopsy : This technique involves removing one or more cells from an embryo to test for genetic conditions before transferring the embryo to the uterus. It is often used in conjunction with preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) to identify embryos with genetic abnormalities or specific inherited disorders.
  • • Option A.
  • • Embryo Biopsy
  • • Option B. Assisted Hatching : This technique involves making a small hole in the zona pellucida (the outer layer of the embryo) to assist the embryo in breaking free during the process of implantation. It's sometimes used to improve the chances of implantation, particularly in certain groups of patients such as older women or those with previous failed IVF cycles.
  • • Option B.
  • • Assisted Hatching
  • • Option C. Oocyte In Vitro Maturation (IVM) : In this process, immature eggs are collected from the ovaries and matured in the laboratory. This is different from conventional IVF, where medication is used to mature the eggs inside the ovaries before they are collected.
  • • Option C.
  • • Oocyte In Vitro Maturation (IVM)
  • • Option D. Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI) : ICSI involves injecting a single sperm directly into an egg to achieve fertilization. It's used especially in cases of severe male factor infertility, where sperm may have difficulty penetrating the egg on their own.
  • • Option D.
  • • Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI)
